objects.name: Mandiant
objects.description: Primary publisher of the report on the Google Cloud Blog Threat Intelligence section.

objects.name: SolarWinds-Core-v2019.4.5220-Hotfix5.msp (trojanized Orion update)
objects.description: Digitally signed but trojanized SolarWinds Orion update used to distribute the SUNBURST backdoor.

objects.name: SUNBURST C2 root domain
objects.description: Root domain leveraged by SUNBURST’s DGA and CNAME-based command-and-control infrastructure.

objects.name: SUNBURST C2 subdomain (EU West 1)
objects.description: DGA-resolved subdomain used by SUNBURST for C2 communications.

objects.name: SUNBURST C2 subdomain (US West 2)
objects.description: DGA-resolved subdomain used by SUNBURST for C2 communications.

objects.name: SUNBURST C2 subdomain (US East 1)
objects.description: DGA-resolved subdomain used by SUNBURST for C2 communications.

objects.name: SUNBURST C2 subdomain (US East 2)
objects.description: DGA-resolved subdomain used by SUNBURST for C2 communications.

objects.name: TEARDROP registry check
objects.description: Registry key checked by TEARDROP dropper prior to decoding and loading its embedded payload.

objects.name: TEARDROP dropper DLL
objects.description: Non-Microsoft-signed DLL (NetSetupSvc.dll) loaded by svchost.exe per TEARDROP behavior; flagged in Windows Defender Exploit Guard logs.

objects.name: Indicator for SolarWinds.Orion.Core.BusinessLayer.dll (MD5)
objects.description: MD5 hash of the backdoored SolarWinds Orion plugin containing the SUNBURST backdoor.

objects.name: Indicator for CORE-2019.4.5220.20574-SolarWinds-Core-v2019.4.5220-Hotfix5.msp (MD5)
objects.description: MD5 hash of the trojanized SolarWinds Orion update package delivering SUNBURST.

objects.name: FireEye
objects.description: Original authoring organization credited in the post; discovered the SolarWinds supply chain attack and released detection signatures and indicators.

objects.name: SolarWinds
objects.description: Vendor of the Orion IT monitoring and management platform whose digitally signed updates were trojanized to distribute the SUNBURST backdoor.

objects.name: Microsoft
objects.description: Acknowledged by the authors for assistance; Windows Defender Exploit Guard eventing referenced in detections.

objects.name: APT29
objects.description: A highly evasive adversary attributed with the SolarWinds supply chain compromise. The group gained access to numerous global public and private organizations via trojanized SolarWinds Orion updates. Post-compromise, they maintained a light malware footprint and relied on legitimate credentials and remote access, performed lateral movement using different credentials than initial access, temporarily replaced files and modified scheduled tasks to execute tools, and removed tooling (including backdoors) once legitimate access was established. They tailored C2 infrastructure hostnames to match victim environments (observable in RDP SSL certificates) and used IPs from the victim’s country via VPS providers to blend in.

objects.name: sunburst
objects.description: An HTTP-based backdoor implanted into the trojanized, SolarWinds-signed plugin SolarWinds.Orion.Core.BusinessLayer.dll. After a dormant period of up to two weeks, it retrieves and executes "Jobs" with capabilities including file transfer and execution, system profiling, rebooting the machine, and disabling system services. Network traffic masquerades as the Orion Improvement Program (OIP) protocol and reconnaissance data is hidden in legitimate plugin configuration files. The backdoor employs multiple obfuscated blocklists to detect and evade forensic and antivirus tools via processes, services, and drivers. It uses a subdomain Domain Generation Algorithm (DGA) against avsvmcloud[.]com, with CNAME responses pointing to C2, and behavior-modifying A-record ranges. C2 messages use DEFLATE compression, single-byte XOR, and split, Base64-encoded fields disguised within GUID/HEX strings in response bodies. Observed associated artifacts include the trojanized update package CORE-2019.4.5220.20574-SolarWinds-Core-v2019.4.5220-Hotfix5.msp (02af7cec58b9a5da1c542b5a32151ba1) and SolarWinds.Orion.Core.BusinessLayer.dll (b91ce2fa41029f6955bff20079468448) signed March 24, 2020. Supported commands include registry queries/edits, file system enumeration and manipulation, task control, and system reboot.

objects.name: teardrop
objects.description: A previously unseen, memory-only dropper used in at least one SUNBURST intrusion to deploy a customized Cobalt Strike BEACON. TEARDROP runs as a service, spawns a thread, reads from a file named "gracious_truth.jpg" (likely with a fake JPG header), checks HKU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\CTF, decodes an embedded payload using a custom rolling XOR algorithm, and manually loads a payload into memory using a custom PE-like format. It exhibited no code overlap with previously known malware.

objects.name: T1012 - Query Registry
objects.description: SUNBURST supports registry interaction through commands such as ReadRegistryValue, SetRegistryValue, and DeleteRegistryValue. TEARDROP checks the HKU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\CTF key. SUNBURST also modifies service start settings via registry to disable targeted services.

objects.name: T1027 - Obfuscated/Deobfuscated Files or Information
objects.description: The campaign uses multiple obfuscation layers: SUNBURST employs obfuscated blocklists, custom XOR schemes and DEFLATE compression for C2 messages, and disguises data as GUID/HEX strings; TEARDROP uses a custom rolling XOR to decode an embedded payload.

objects.name: T1057 - Process Discovery
objects.description: SUNBURST enumerates process names and hashes them to compare against embedded blocklists, identifying analysis and security tools to evade detection.

objects.name: T1070.004 - Indicator Removal on Host: File Deletion
objects.description: Operators regularly removed their tools and even removed backdoors once they had achieved legitimate remote access to reduce their on-host footprint.

objects.name: T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
objects.description: SUNBURST communicates with C2 over HTTP(S) using GET/POST requests with JSON payloads, masquerading as Orion Improvement Program traffic.

objects.name: T1071.004 - Application Layer Protocol: DNS
objects.description: SUNBURST uses a subdomain DGA and resolves subdomains of avsvmcloud[.]com, receiving CNAME responses that point to C2 infrastructure and guide targeting/behavior.

objects.name: T1083 - File and Directory Discovery
objects.description: SUNBURST implements file system discovery and manipulation via commands such as GetFileSystemEntries, FileExists, GetFileHash, WriteFile, and DeleteFile.

objects.name: T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer
objects.description: SUNBURST supports transferring and executing files, and in at least one instance the operators used TEARDROP to deploy Cobalt Strike BEACON.

objects.name: T1132.001 - Data Encoding: Standard Encoding
objects.description: SUNBURST encodes outbound data using Base64 within JSON fields and employs DEFLATE compression and single-byte XOR before transmission.

objects.name: T1195.002 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
objects.description: Digitally signed SolarWinds Orion software updates from March–May 2020 were trojanized to deliver the SUNBURST backdoor via SolarWinds.Orion.Core.BusinessLayer.dll.

objects.name: T1518 - Software Discovery
objects.description: SUNBURST enumerates installed services and drivers and records results in configuration fields to assess the environment.

objects.name: T1518.001 - Software Discovery: Security Software Discovery
objects.description: The backdoor’s blocklists specifically target forensic and antivirus processes, services, and drivers to evade defenses.

objects.name: T1543.003 - Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service
objects.description: TEARDROP runs as a service, and SUNBURST disables selected services by setting HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\services\<name>\Start to 4 (disabled).

objects.name: T1553.002 - Subvert Trust Controls: Code Signing
objects.description: Trojanized SolarWinds Orion updates were digitally signed, enabling the malicious DLL to appear legitimate and blend into normal operations.

objects.name: T1568.002 - Dynamic Resolution: Domain Generation Algorithms
objects.description: SUNBURST generates subdomains for avsvmcloud[.]com using a DGA that incorporates a victim-specific userId and encoded domain name, influencing targeting and C2 resolution via CNAME.

objects.name: T1569.002 - System Services: Service Execution
objects.description: The operators executed tools by temporarily replacing legitimate utilities and manipulating scheduled tasks; TEARDROP itself executes as a service.

objects.name: T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure
objects.description: Attackers operated dedicated infrastructure with hostnames that mimicked victim environments (leaked in RDP SSL certificates) and used VPS IP addresses originating from the victim’s country to reduce suspicion.

objects.name: Analisi Malware: Sunburst
objects.description: This report contains technical analysis and indicators associated with malware. sunburst.
